Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: THE PHYLOGENY AND EVOLUTION OF WORLD TACHINIDAE (DIPTERA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The family Tachinidae contains nearly 10,000 described species of beneficial parasitic flies. As enemies of other insects, particularly herbivores, tachinids are important regulators of host populations in natural and agricultural ecosystems. They help in the natural control of numerous pest insects and have been effectively used in biological control of invasive pests. Despite their diversity and ecological importance, we know little about their interactions with hosts and how these have developed over time. The taxonomic difficulty and lack of a robust classification of tachinids has hindered both basic and applied research. The goals of this project are to reconstruct relationships among groups of tachinid flies using molecular and traditional methods and then use these results to produce a stable classification and to understand patterns of host-use and other life history traits. Another key goal is to broadly distribute taxonomic and biological information on tachinids to researchers and practitioners.

Tachinidae are the most important group of insect parasitoids outside of the wasps. A sound grasp of their history and a reliable taxonomic infrastructure are necessary to understand their roles as enemies, the evolution of their diverse attack strategies, and the causes of their rapid and rampant diversification. Such an understanding can guide the selection of the most effective tachinid biological control agents in agricultural and forest systems and limit the potential negative impacts upon non-targets. It will also inform broad issues in biology such as biogeography, ecological specialization, and the causes of adaptive diversification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tachinidae comprise a clade of higher Diptera (i.e., true flies) defined largely by presence of an enlarged postscutellum and obligate parasitism of arthropod hosts. With over 8,500 species known and many more awaiting description, Tachinidae is among the most diverse families of Diptera. They are surpassed only by the Hymenoptera (wasps) in terms of insect parasitism. Tachinids have likely experienced such impressive evolutionary success in part due to their varied use of hosts, which constitute 14 orders of arthropods. Their attack of plant pests, such as caterpillars and true bugs, make them important natural regulators of pest populations. Despite their great diversity and importance, our knowledge of their evolutionary relationships is paltry.

The chief focus of this project was to conduct the first molecular (i.e., through use of DNA sequences) phylogenetic analysis of the agriculturally important tachinid subfamily Phasiinae (Diptera: Tachinidae) to infer how the myriad genera and tribes within it are related to one another. The Phasiinae constitute the smallest of the four subfamilies of Tachinidae yet still contain over 600 described species belonging to about 100 genera. Some of the most extreme morphological divergence within the Tachinidae is found in this subfamily. Phasiines differ dramatically in size and appearance, from among the smallest of tachinids (e.g., Catharosia spp.: <2mm) to among the largest (e.g., Lophosia spp.: ca. 1 cm). Some phasiines are traditional looking, black and grey tachinids having large abdominal bristles, while others are beautiful mimics of wasps and bees, often brightly colored and devoid of large bristles. 

Phylogenetic, or evolutionary relationships were inferred from 7600 bases of nuclear DNA from three genes [(carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase 2, aspartate transcarbamylase, and dihydroorotase (CAD), molybdenum cofactor sulfurase (MCS), lethal giant larvae (LGL)] obtained from 128 species representing 80 tachinid genera plus a handful of non-tachinids from closely related fly families. Special emphasis was placed on inclusion of genera with controversial taxonomic placement. The resultant total evidence phylogenetic tree (i.e., one based on all of our data) was used to reconstruct the evolution of significant adaptive traits within the Tachinidae and test prior hypotheses about the classification of Phasiinae. Subfamily placement of the tribes Eutherini, Epigrimyiini, Litophasia, Strongygastrini, and Parerigonini was confidently recovered, the former three within the sister clade Dexiinae and the latter two within Phasiinae. The Imitomyiini were tentatively placed within Phasiinae. Ancestral state reconstruction suggests a dominant and persistent trend in Phasiinae to evolve piercing structures used to insert eggs directly into host tissues. A single potential synapomorphy of Phasiinae, an elongated hypandrium (9th abdominal sternite), was identified. Using this phylogeny the classification of worldwide phasiine genera and tribes was revised.

A related side project involved a survey of phasiine biodiversity in Great Smoky Mountains National Park (TN, NC). Species identifications were made using a combination of morphological and molecular data, the latter from 900 base pairs of MCS. In total, 221 specimens representing 26 phasiine species were collected and studied. Of these, 21 species are newly recorded from the park, four are new records for Tennessee, and two are new records for North Carolina. All 12 eastern Nearctic phasiine genera were captured. Updated identification keys and DNA barcoding sequences for the eastern Nearctic Phasiinae were generated, both of which will aid future researchers in identification.

The inferred phylogeny and resultant revised predictive tribal and generic classification for the Phasiinae will aid researchers interested in testing hypotheses about the evolution and biology of these interesting flies. A total of almost one million base pairs of fly DNA from CAD, MCS, & LGL were made available to the scientific community via deposition of our sequences to GenBank. One graduate student supported by the award matriculated and immediately secured a faculty position at Union University in Jackson, TN. The PI also worked extensively with personnel of a collaboratively linked award at Wright State University. Besides the dissertation and several presentations at professional societal meetings, this work will be disseminated through refereed journal articles, the first of which will be submitted to Systematic Entomology, in late March 2017.
